overview: The legislature finds that patrons leaving a liquor establishment can adversely affect neighboring residents and users of nearby public facilities. [1] The legislature further finds that section 281-39.5, Hawaii Revised Statutes, currently applies only to the issuance of new liquor licenses, but not the renewal of current licenses, thus creating a safe harbor for existing establishments seeking a renewal of their liquor license. [1] Accordingly, the purpose of this Act is to provide communities the opportunity to protest the renewal of certain liquor licenses. [1]
appropriations: This measure does not contain an appropriation. [1]
assumptions_and_methodology: The provided legislative documents do not contain information on the assumptions and methodology used for a fiscal impact statement. [1]
agency_impact: This measure provides that the Liquor Commission or other licensing agency of each county shall deny the renewal of certain current liquor licenses upon receipt of sufficient protests. [1] By applying the protest provision to license renewals, this measure will likely increase the administrative workload for county liquor licensing agencies. [1]
economic_impact: The provided legislative documents do not contain information regarding the economic impact of this measure. [1]
policy_impact: This Act amends section 281-39.5, Hawaii Revised Statutes, to apply to both the issuance of new liquor licenses and the renewal of existing liquor licenses. [1] This change is intended to provide communities the opportunity to protest the renewal of certain liquor licenses, which they may wish to do after they have learned more about the establishment. [1] The Act does not affect rights and duties that matured, penalties that were incurred, and proceedings that were begun before its effective date. [1]
revenue_sources: The provided legislative documents do not specify any revenue sources related to this measure. [1]
